text: This is a little off topic since it's visualization advice and not specifically Julia advice but I thought I'd ask here anyway, feel free to ignore me. I have this hideous plot with lines spaced too close together. Any idea how I could represent it a little better? I'm trying to avoid splitting the lines into multiple graphs.

elements.text: This is a little off topic since it's visualization advice and not specifically Julia advice but I thought I'd ask here anyway, feel free to ignore me. I have this hideous plot with lines spaced too close together. Any idea how I could represent it a little better? I'm trying to avoid splitting the lines into multiple graphs.

text: I played with transparency and marker size a bit and it looks a little better

elements.text: I played with transparency and marker size a bit and it looks a little better

text:
Typically, I think you want only one visual element to change per thing changing. And if something is the same, there should be a visual element that's the same. By visual element, I mean color OR marker shape OR line style etc

So for example, I'd probably use one shape to represent T6A things and a different one for T8A (I'm assuming different T6A things are meaningfully connected somehow) and then different colors for the other part. So eg the top 6 things would only have 3 colors and 2 shapes.

elements.text:
Typically, I think you want only one visual element to change per thing changing. And if something is the same, there should be a visual element that's the same. By visual element, I mean color OR marker shape OR line style etc

So for example, I'd probably use one shape to represent T6A things and a different one for T8A (I'm assuming different T6A things are meaningfully connected somehow) and then different colors for the other part. So eg the top 6 things would only have 3 colors and 2 shapes.

text: The bottom things are harder, but (knowing nothing about what these things actually mean) you might use the same color or a slightly different shade of the same color for Ss14 and Ss15.

elements.text: The bottom things are harder, but (knowing nothing about what these things actually mean) you might use the same color or a slightly different shade of the same color for Ss14 and Ss15.

text: Also, when it comes to colors selection, use divergent colors if your things are categorical, only use continuous colors if you're representing continuous values. And if that's the case, you probably want to use a color scheme that moves through a small range of colors

elements.text: Also, when it comes to colors selection, use divergent colors if your things are categorical, only use continuous colors if you're representing continuous values. And if that's the case, you probably want to use a color scheme that moves through a small range of colors

text: Thank you so much for the advice, it has been so valuable. I have updated the plot and it's actually readable now! For reference, these are algorithm, the number after the T refers to the order of the algorithm and the number symbol after the underscore is the family. Ss14, Ys7 and KLs9 are similar so I gave them somewhat similar symbols, and similarly for the last two algorithms. Thank you again, I really appreciate it.

elements.text: Thank you so much for the advice, it has been so valuable. I have updated the plot and it's actually readable now! For reference, these are algorithm, the number after the T refers to the order of the algorithm and the number symbol after the underscore is the family. Ss14, Ys7 and KLs9 are similar so I gave them somewhat similar symbols, and similarly for the last two algorithms. Thank you again, I really appreciate it.

text: Not sure if this is suitable for this particular case, but if what you want to emphasize is the series-to-series variation rather than the specific values of each series you could pick one series to be the "reference series" (or use a generic "model series") and then plot the other values relative to the reference series by either dividing by or subtracting the reference series as appropriate.  That can make better use of the plot's "dynamic range".

elements.text: Not sure if this is suitable for this particular case, but if what you want to emphasize is the series-to-series variation rather than the specific values of each series you could pick one series to be the "reference series" (or use a generic "model series") and then plot the other values relative to the reference series by either dividing by or subtracting the reference series as appropriate.  That can make better use of the plot's "dynamic range".

text: add frame=:box, put legend bottomright, and maybe do a lens on top left on a representative part of the plot

elements.text: add frame=:box, put legend bottomright, and maybe do a lens on top left on a representative part of the plot

text: Much better! I would not change the symbols for the bottom ones though. You're saying square "means" T8 and circle "means" T6. You have the right idea with making similar things visually similar, but since you're using color to indicate the family, if Ss14, ys7 and KLs9 are similar, give them similar colors.

elements.text: Much better! I would not change the symbols for the bottom ones though. You're saying square "means" T8 and circle "means" T6. You have the right idea with making similar things visually similar, but since you're using color to indicate the family, if Ss14, ys7 and KLs9 are similar, give them similar colors.

text:
To make this point really explicit, you could even have empty :white_large_square: for T8 and empty :white_circle: for T6, and then just colored lines for the families underneath in the legend

:white_circle: T6
:white_large_square: T8
-blue- TJ
-green- SF
-red- CMP
-light orange- Ss14
-med orange- Ys7
-dark orange- KLs9
Etc...

text: This isn’t really helping with your visualization, but I don’t remember seeing a graph with both axis exponential. What would the lines look like if both axis were linear?

elements.text: This isn’t really helping with your visualization, but I don’t remember seeing a graph with both axis exponential. What would the lines look like if both axis were linear?

text: I should have written ”both axes” apparently.

elements.text: I should have written ”both axes” apparently.

text: They’d be straight line in linear axes?

elements.text: They’d be straight line in linear axes?

text: Double-log is very common

elements.text: Double-log is very common

text: Given that the slope is >1 here, they would be upward-curving exponential in linear space

elements.text: Given that the slope is >1 here, they would be upward-curving exponential in linear space

text: I took your advice again and here's the third round of edits! It looks much better and doesn't waste white space, and the lens helps a little as well. Now the T6 family is all circles, T8 is all rectangles, TJ, SF, CMP have their own colors, and Ss14, Ys17, KLs9 are shades of orange (they're all circles) while Ss15, KLs17 are shades of sky blue (they're both rectangles). It's so much more readable now, thank you everyone, I've learned more about plotting than 7 years in undergrad/grad school :D

elements.text: I took your advice again and here's the third round of edits! It looks much better and doesn't waste white space, and the lens helps a little as well. It's so much more readable now, thank you everyone, I've learned more about plotting than 7 years in undergrad/grad school :D
